TEXT:
Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   CT head: Left frontal hypoattenuation consistent with chronic infarct.
   No acute bleed or infarct. MRI if suspicious of CVA.
   CT Chest:  No large PE but unable to assess smaller
   segmental/subsegmental PEs because of timing of contrast. Bilateral
   small pleural effustions and bibasilar atelectasis. Calcification of
   aorta.
   CT Abd: Strophic pancreas. Calcification of aorta.
   ABGs: 7.48/36/119 on NRB -> 7.44/38/66 on CPAP. Was taken off CPAP put
   back on NRB and satting 97%. Also turned down fluids to 50mL/hour. CXR
   with no change although final read pending. Looks as if trachea is
   small but the same as on previous CXRs and has not been commented on.
   Called at 12:30 for agitation. Patient afebrile, HR 90s, BP 148/78.
   Saying will arrest the nurses and trying to climb out of bed. Oriented
   to self only. Gave 0.25mg Haldol and then 0.5mg more as patient was
   still agitated.
   Called at 2:30am for agitation. Went to assess patient and he was
   sleeping. Tachycardic at 106bpm. Tachypnic 27/min. Afebrile with O2sats
   in high 90s. Did not give more sedation as was sleeping.
   Called at 3:30 for HTN BP 165/70. Had been 148/78 on last look. Patient
   had adequate UOP. No intervention.
   Called at 5:30 to assess patient for agitation. Patient tachypnic rate
   24, Tachycardic rate 105, Normotensive SBP120s, and O2sat 94-97% on
   NRB. Patient pulling at condom catheter and trying to get out of bed.
   Reported pain in his back. Given 2mg morphine for pain as had not had
   any pain medications for 24hours.

   Penicillins

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 72-year-old male admitted to the ICU with multiple medical conditions including a chronic infarct in the left frontal region of the brain, small pleural effusions, bibasilar atelectasis, calcification of the aorta, and a strophic pancreas. The patient's ABGs show improvement in oxygenation when placed on CPAP, but was later taken off CPAP and put back on NRB with an O2 sat of 97%. The patient has been agitated several times during the night, requiring sedation with Haldol. There have been no changes in the CXR, except for a potentially small trachea. The patient's vital signs have been fluctuating, with episodes of hypertension and tachycardia. The patient is also experiencing pain in the back and has been given morphine for pain relief. 

Potential Medical Complications:
Based on the provided information, potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to the presence of small pleural effusions and bibasilar atelectasis.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE) due to prolonged immobility and risk factors such as a strophic pancreas.
3. Infection or sepsis due to the presence of a strophic pancreas, which can increase the risk of infection.
4. Acute kidney injury (AK

   Mono:5.4 %, Eos:0.4 %, Lactic Acid:1.1 mmol/L, Albumin:3.7 g/dL,

   Assessment and Plan
   70-yo man w/ HTN, HL, LBP s/p L4-S1 decompression / fusion, w/ post-op
   course c/b delirium as well as an event of hypotension, tachycardia,
   and hypoxia. Hypotension and tachycardia resolved, hypoxia is
   persistent.
   .
   #. Hypoxia - Concern for PE given timing w/ significant HD compromise
   including hypotension and tachycardia, both of which have now resolved.
   Lungs clear on exam and CXR clear. ABG c/w hypoxia as well. Also, pt
   may have aspirated in setting of altered mental status.
   - check CTA to r/o PE
   - consider TTE to look for e/o R-heart strain
   - consider bubble study on TTE to look for e/o left-to-right shunt
   - control agitation as below
   - consider intubation w/ bronchoscopy to eval for secretions given
   upper airway sounds
   - albuterol / ipratropium PRN
   - monitor serial ABGs
   .
   #. Delirium - Post-op delirium, likely [**2-27**] EtOH withdrawal, also
   consider paradoxical effect to benzodiazepines in the elderly.
   Infection unlikely given lack of fever or elevated WBC. Hypoxia may be
   contributing. Also consider post-op pain as pt has not yet received any
   pain meds.
   - hold ativan CIWA now
   - use Haldol for delirium
   - cont pain control as below for surgery, wound avoid narcotics
   - f/u Head CT results
   - cont eval and treatment for hypoxia as above
   .
   #. [**Name (NI) 4602**] - Pt w/ LBP s/p lumbar decompression / fusion.
   - f/u Neuro-surgery recs, appreciate involvement
   - f/u Abdominal CT to eval for abdominal / RP bleeding
   - pain control, would avoid narcotics given mental status and avoid
   NSAIDs given recent surgery, consider Tylenol vs. low-dose narcotics
   .
   #. HTN - cont home Atenolol
   .
   #. HL - cont home statin
   .
   #. FEN - NPO, IVF overnight, consider NGT w/ TFs, electrolyte repletion
   .
   #. Access - PIVs
   .
   #. PPx - SQ Heparin, pneumoboots, home PPI, bowel regimen, restraints,
   maintain HOB <30 degrees at all times with bedrest
   .
   #. Code - FULL CODE
   .
   #. Dispo - MICU for now
Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, left below-knee amputation, and post-operative delirium. The patient is currently admitted to the ICU due to an event of hypotension, tachycardia, and hypoxia. His recent surgeries include L4-S1 decompression and fusion.

The patient's vital signs have been fluctuating throughout the day, with episodes of agitation and tachycardia. His oxygen saturation has been in the high 90s on NRB (nasal rapid flow) and CPAP (continuous positive airway pressure). The patient's respiratory support includes NRB and CPAP.

The patient's CT head shows a left frontal hypoattenuation consistent with chronic infarct, with no acute bleed or infarct. The CT chest reveals no large pulmonary embolism (PE), but smaller segmental/subsegmental PEs cannot be assessed due to the timing of contrast. There are also bilateral small pleural effusions and bibasilar atelectasis. The CT abdomen shows stenotic pancreas and calcification of the aorta.

The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and lactate levels. The patient's blood glucose level is within normal range. Other lab values such as hemoglobin (Hb), hematocrit (Hct), platelet count (Plt), creat

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and lower back pain post lumbar decompression/fusion surgery.
- He presented with post-operative delirium, hypotension, tachycardia, and hypoxia, which have since resolved except for persistent hypoxia.
- CT chest showed no large pulmonary embolism but could not rule out small subsegmental PEs due to timing of contrast.
- The patient has bilateral small pleural effusions, bibasilar atelectasis, and calcification of the aorta.
- ABGs indicate hypoxia.
- The patient's vital signs have fluctuated, with episodes of agitation, tachycardia, and hypertension.
- Review of systems is unchanged from admission except for pain in his back.
- Physical examination findings include not assessed peripheral vascular status, skin, and neurologic status.
- Laboratory results show slightly elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin, normal platelet count, and various other lab values within normal range.
- Assessment and plan include concerns for hypoxia potentially due to pulmonary embolism or aspiration, delirium possibly related to ethanol withdrawal or paradoxical effect of benzodiazepines, and ongoing monitoring and treatment for these conditions.
- Other plans include follow-up with neurosurgery, evaluation of abdominal CT, pain control, management of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and other

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and lumbar back pain post laminectomy/fusion. He was admitted with acute hypotension, tachycardia, and hypoxia, which have since resolved. The patient remains hypoxic despite being on CPAP and has a persistent low-grade fever. He is agitated and delirious, but responsive to commands. His physical examination reveals inspiratory wheezes, tachypnea, and poor air flow, although good airflow is noted through bilateral lung fields. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 165/70 mmHg, heart rate of 106 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94-97% on NRB. His labs show normal white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelets, but elevated creatinine and lactate levels. The patient's medical history includes a stenotic aorta with calcification, chronic left frontal infarct, and bibasilar atelectasis. He has allergies to penicillins and has not had any pain medications in the past 24 hours. The patient is currently on multiple medications including senna, docusate, PPI, atenolol, heparin, vitamin D, rosuvastatin, albuterol nebs Q4hours, and Tylenol PRN.

Potential medical complications:
1. Hypoxia: The patient's persistent hypoxia requires further evaluation and management. Possible causes include pulmonary embolism (PE), aspiration pneumonia, or underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary syndrome (COPD). Further diagnostic tests such as a repeat CT chest or a ventilation-perfusion scan may be necessary to rule out PE. If the patient is suspected to have aspirated, broad-spectrum antibiotics may be considered.

2. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status and agitation suggest delirium. The cause could be multifactorial, including pain, possible alcohol withdrawal, benzodiazepine paradoxical effect, or infection. Holding the patient's benzodiazepines and providing adequate pain control may help improve his mental status. Close monitoring and frequent re-evaluation are essential.

3. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure remains elevated despite being on atenolol. Adjustments to his antihypertensive therapy may be necessary, and close monitoring of blood pressure is required.

4. Back pain: The patient complains of back pain, which could be related to his recent lumbar decompression/fusion surgery. Adequate pain control is crucial for his comfort and overall condition.

5. Infection: Although the patient's white blood cell count is within normal limits, his elevated lactate level suggests possible infection or sepsis. Cultures should be monitored, and appropriate antibiotics should be considered if there are signs of infection.

6. Fluid balance: The patient has had a negative fluid balance

- Postoperatively, the patient experienced delirium, hypotension, tachycardia, and persistent hypoxia.
- The patient's hypoxia is a concern for possible pulmonary embolism (PE), but CT scan ruled out major PEs, although small subsegmental PEs cannot be completely ruled out.
- The patient's lungs are clear on examination, and chest X-ray is unremarkable.
- There is a possibility of aspiration due to altered mental status, but the patient seems to be oxygenating well on room air.
- A sleep consult suggests that the patient may have obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), which could contribute to his hypoxia, especially during delirium.
- The patient's delirium is likely postoperative in nature, and the use of benzodiazepines may have paradoxically worsened his delirium. Holding benzodiazepines and administering haloperidol has led to improvement.
- The patient complains of back pain, for which morphine was given, resulting in improved symptoms.
- The patient's white blood cell count is slightly elevated, with a normal platelet count.
- The patient's electrolytes are within normal limits, except for slightly low potassium levels.
- The patient's kidney function

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and lumbar back pain who underwent L4-S1 decompression and fusion surgery. He presented to the ICU with delirium, hypotension, tachycardia, and hypoxia. His symptoms resolved except for persistent hypoxia. The patient has a positive urine culture for >100,000 GNR and is allergic to penicillins. He was started on IV Bactrim due to the allergy and because ciprofloxacin can lower the seizure threshold. His vital signs are stable, but he continues to experience hypoxia despite clear lung sounds on examination. The ABG shows hypoxia as well. The patient may have aspirated in the setting of altered mental status, although the chest X-ray remains unchanged. A sleep consult suggests that he may have obstructive sleep apnea, but it is difficult to ascertain whether it is contributing to his hypoxia. The patient's delirium is attributed to post-operative factors and possibly benzodiazepine paradoxical effect, rather than alcohol withdrawal. The patient's pain has improved with morphine, and he has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The plan includes treating the urinary tract infection with Bactrim, evaluating for alcohol withdrawal, considering haloperidol for agitation, continuing evaluation and treatment for hypoxia, following up with neurosurgery recommendations, providing
